Chess Pieces Fundamentals The pawn The knight The bishop The rook The queen The king Capture Protection Check Get out of check Checkmate Castling En passant Stalemate Piece value Check in two Basic Tactics Intermediate Tactics Pawn Endgames Rook Endgames The pin The skewer The fork Discovered attacks Double check Overloaded pieces Being forced to move Greek gift sacrifice Deflection Attraction Counter check Undermining Opposition Basic rook endgames For White For Black Time left Stop Play All lessons: %1$d out of 92 taken Chess basics lessons: %1$d out of 42 taken Tactical concepts lessons: %1$d out of 40 taken Opening lessons: %1$d out of 10 taken Coordinate lessons: %1$d taken Coordinate Settings Save Show coordinates Show pieces Play as white Play as black Minutes (0–5) Seconds (0–59) Adjust timer 3 2 1 Go! Correct coordinates: %1$d Lesson %1$d Previous lesson Next lesson Previous step Next step Lesson Finished Previous opening Next opening Opening Finished
It moves forward only. Pawns move forward, but capture diagonally! A pawn on the second rank can move 2 squares at once! When they reach the other side of the board, they become a stronger piece!
It moves in an L shape. They are jumping around. They can jump over pieces!
It moves diagonally. One light-squared bishop, one dark-squared bishop.
It moves in straight lines.
It moves diagonally and in straight lines.
The most important piece. The king can move one square at a time!
Take the opponent pieces!
Keep your pieces safe by escaping attacks. Keep your pieces safe by defending.
Attack the king, putting it in check.
Defend your king by escaping the check. Defend your king by blocking the check. Defend your king by taking the attacking piece.
Attack your opponent\'s king in a way that cannot be defended, delivering a checkmate.
You can castle king-side! You can castle queen-side! You cannot castle if the king is in check or would pass through a square under attack.
En passant can only be performed if your pawn is on the 5th rank (for white) or the 4th rank (for black). En passant can only be performed immediately after the opponent moves their pawn.
Stalemate occurs when a player has no legal moves but is not in check.
Queen > Rook > Bishop > Knight > Pawn Take the piece with the highest value! Do not exchange a higher valued piece for a less valuable one.
A pinned piece cannot move without exposing a more valuable piece behind it, often the king or queen. Use the pin to attack your opponent\'s pieces, forcing them to protect the pinned piece or lose a more valuable one. Look for opportunities to pin your opponent\'s pieces during both your attack and defense.
A skewer is an attack upon two pieces in a line and is similar to a pin. A skewer is sometimes described as a "reverse pin." The difference is that in a skewer, the more valuable piece is in front of the piece of lesser value.
A fork attacks two or more pieces at once, forcing your opponent into a difficult choice. Knights are especially effective at forking due to their unique movement pattern. Look for opportunities to fork high-value pieces, such as the king and queen.
A discovered attack occurs when you move a piece, revealing an attack by another piece. Use discovered attacks to threaten multiple targets simultaneously. Look for opportunities where moving one piece will create a dangerous attack.
A double check occurs when two pieces attack the king simultaneously. Double check always forces the king to move—blocking or capturing won\'t help. Use a double check to create powerful attacks and limit your opponent\'s responses.
Overloaded pieces are assigned too many defensive tasks at once. Identify pieces that are defending multiple important squares or pieces. Force an overloaded piece to abandon one of its duties to create a winning tactic.
Use forced moves to dictate the game\'s pace and create opportunities for your strategy. Recognize when your opponent has no choice but to move, turning the tide in your favor.
The Greek Gift Sacrifice involves sacrificing a bishop to expose the opponent\'s king.
Deflection involves forcing an opponent\'s piece away from its defending position to create an opportunity. Identify key defending pieces and consider how to lure them away from critical squares. Use threats, such as attacks or captures, to distract the opponent\'s piece and weaken their defense. Deflecting a defender can open up lines for your pieces, increasing your attacking potential.
Attraction involves drawing an opponent\'s piece to a more vulnerable position to exploit its new location. Be mindful of how moving an opponent\'s piece can expose their king or weaken their defense. Use threats to entice the opponent\'s piece into an unfavorable square or situation. Combine attractions with other tactics to create powerful combinations that capitalize on your opponent\'s missteps.
A counter check occurs when you check your opponent\'s king immediately after being checked yourself. Use a counter check to shift the pressure back to your opponent and potentially gain the initiative. Remember, a counter check can disrupt your opponent\'s plans and provide you with tactical advantages.
Target the defenders of key squares or pieces to create imbalances in your opponent\'s setup. Undermining involves attacking the supporting pieces of your opponent to weaken their position. Remember, an effective undermining strategy can lead to tactical advantages and material gain.
Opposition is crucial for controlling key squares in king endgames. Move your king to maintain a direct line with your opponent’s king, keeping the opposition. The player with the opposition can control the movement and restrict the opponent\'s king. Mastering opposition can be the difference between winning or drawing a pawn endgame.
Keep your rook active to restrict your opponent\'s king. Use checks to drive the opponent\'s king towards the edge of the board. Place your rook behind passed pawns, either yours or your opponent\'s.
Ruy Lopez (Spanish Opening) Control the center Start by playing e4 to control the center and prepare for quick development. Develop your bishop Move your bishop to b5 on the third move to put pressure on your opponent\'s knight at c6, indirectly attacking the center. Castle early After developing your bishop, aim to castle on the king-side quickly to secure your king and complete your development. Avoid unnecessary exchanges In the Ruy Lopez, try to avoid exchanging your bishop on b5 too early. This piece is useful for maintaining pressure on black\'s position. Plan your pawn breaks Look for opportunities to play d4 to take control of the center, but be careful of black\'s responses. Watch out for black\'s counter-play Watch out for black\'s move a6, which tries to kick your bishop away and possibly prepare b5 to gain queen-side space.
Italian Game Control the center early Start with e4 and then develop your knight to f3 to support the center and prepare for quick development. Develop your bishop to c4 On the third move, play bishop c4 to target the f7 square, which is a weak point in black\'s position, especially early in the game. Castle early Once your bishop and knight are developed, aim to castle king-side to ensure your king\'s safety and prepare to bring your rook into the game. Watch out for black\'s counter-play Be careful of black\'s move knight g4, which can target your bishop on c4 or create pressure on your king-side. Quiet or aggressive game You can either play calmly by developing pieces or aim for an aggressive pawn push with c3 and d4 to open the center. Don\'t rush to exchange The Italian Game is about maintaining piece activity. Try to keep your pieces active rather than exchanging them early.
Queen\'s Gambit Control the center The Queen\'s Gambit starts with d4 and c4, aiming to control the center and challenge black to respond. Don\'t worry about the pawn If black takes the pawn on c4 (accepted variation), you can regain it later with moves like e3 and bishop takes c4. Focus on quick development. Keep your structure solid In the declined variation, black usually plays e6. Focus on developing your pieces. Knight to f3 and bishop to g5 or e2 to keep your center intact. Quick piece development Aim to develop your pieces quickly. Knights to c3 and f3 and bishops to g5 and e2 help control the board. Consider long-term plans Queen\'s Gambit positions are usually about maintaining a strong pawn structure and planning for a central breakthrough with e4. King-side safety Aim to castle king-side early for safety while you continue putting pressure on black\'s position.
London System Start with d4 and bishop f4 The London System is easy to learn because it has a consistent setup-play d4, then develop your bishop to f4, followed by e3, c3, and knight f3. Solid structure The London System is known for being solid and hard to break. Your pawn structure (d4, e3, c3) provides a lot of stability. Develop sensibly After placing your pawns, develop your knights to f3 and d2, and consider pushing your pawn to h3 to give your bishop a safe square. Keep the bishop active Your light-square bishop is crucial. Keep it outside the pawn chain to maximize its activity. Flexible play The London System is versatile and can be played against many responses from black. Keep developing sensibly and look for opportunities to expand in the center or the king-side. Don\'t rush to attack The London System is more about patience and building a strong position before launching an attack. Wait for the right moment when your pieces are well-placed.
Scotch Game Start aggressively The Scotch Game is an aggressive way to challenge the center early. By pushing the d4 pawn, you force an immediate clash in the middle of the board. Open up the position The Scotch Game often leads to an open game, which means faster piece development and attacking chances. Develop your pieces quickly to make the most of the open lines. Look out for exchanges Be prepared for early pawn exchanges in the center. These trades can open the e-file, allowing your rooks to become active later in the game. Control the center After the exchange, try to maintain control over the central squares, especially e4 and d4. This will give you a strong foundation for launching attacks. Develop your pieces efficiently Get your knights and bishops out quickly, aiming to castle early. Central control combined with quick development can create powerful attacking opportunities. Watch out for black\'s counter-play In the Scotch Game, black can counterattack with moves like queen f6 or bishop b4 check, putting pressure on your center. Make sure you stay alert to threats while advancing your own plans.
Sicilian Defense Respond to e4 with c5 The Sicilian Defense starts with c5, aiming to control the d4 square and create an asymmetrical pawn structure for dynamic play. Expect an aggressive game The Sicilian often leads to tactical and attacking positions, especially from white. Be prepared for sharp play where both sides aim for early attacking chances. Develop the knights quickly Place your knights on c6 and f6 to control the center and prepare for flexible pawn pushes. Fight for the center with d6 Play d6 to support your c5 pawn and prepare for development. This move also opens up lines for your light-squared bishop. Counterattack when possible One of the key strengths of the Sicilian is the opportunity for black to counterattack. Moves like a6 and b5 help expand on the queen-side, aiming for counter-play and attacking chances.
French Defense Respond to e4 with e6 The French Defense begins with e6, preparing to support the d5 pawn push on the next move. This structure aims to create a solid, albeit somewhat passive, position. Prepare for d5 After e4 e6, aim to play d5 to challenge white\'s center. This move helps you establish control over the center and sets the stage for your pieces to develop. Watch your pawn structure The French Defense often leads to a locked center with pawns on d5 and e4. Be cautious about the pawn structure and how it affects your piece mobility and plans. Focus on counterattacking opportunities The French Defense is known for its counterattacking potential. Look for chances to challenge white\'s center with moves like c5 and f6, especially when your pieces are well-coordinated. Develop your bishop Your light-squared bishop can become "bad" if it\'s stuck behind your pawns. Consider developing it to b7 or exchange it for white\'s active pieces.
Caro-Kann Defense Respond to e4 with c6 The Caro-Kann Defense begins with c6, preparing to play d5 on the next move. This setup aims to create a solid pawn structure while allowing for piece development. Prepare for d5 Play d5 to challenge white\'s central pawn on e4. This central push helps establish control and creates a foundation for your position. Develop your pieces Focus on developing your pieces efficiently. Bring your knights to f6 and c6, and consider moving your dark-squared bishop to g7 with g6 to increase its activity. Watch your pawn structure The Caro-Kann often leads to a solid pawn structure with pawns on c6 and d5. Be mindful of how this structure influences your piece activity and look for opportunities to break the center with e5 later. Keep your king safe Plan to castle king-side for safety. Ensure that your pawn structure is solid and that there are no potential threats from white before committing to king-side castling.
King\'s Indian Defense Start with knight f6 The King\'s Indian Defense begins with knight f6, aiming to control the center and prepare for g6 to move your dark-squared bishop to g7. Prepare bishop g7 After playing knight f6, plan to play g6 and bishop g7. This setup gives your bishop long-range control over the center and prepares for a solid king-side structure. Establish your center After playing g6, consider advancing your pawns with d6 and e5 to challenge white\'s central control. This setup allows for a dynamic and flexible pawn structure. Develop your pieces Focus on developing your pieces. Bring your knights to f6 and d7, and aim to place your rooks on open files to increase their activity. Pawn storm The King\'s Indian often leads to aggressive pawn storms from white on the king-side. Be prepared to counter these threats and look for opportunities to counterattack. Counter-play While white focuses on the king-side, consider creating counter-play on the queen-side with moves like b5 and c5. This can distract white from their attack and give you play
Pirc Defense Start with d6 The Pirc Defense begins with d6, allowing you to develop your pieces flexibly while inviting white to occupy the center. Prepare bishop g7 After playing d6, consider g6 and bishop to g7. This setup provides solid control over the center and helps in king safety. Challenge the center Be prepared to challenge white\'s center with moves like e5 or c5. Timing is crucial. Strike back when white has overextended their pawns. Develop for a counter-play Focus on developing your knights to f6 and d7, and consider bringing your rooks to the center once the pawns are more established. Good development is key to counter-play. Stay flexible The Pirc Defense is a hyper-modern opening, allowing you to adapt to white\'s plans. Pay attention to your opponent\'s setup and adjust your strategy accordingly.
Tips and Tricks Control the center of the board with pawns and pieces. Develop all your pieces before moving the same one repeatedly. Avoid moving your queen too early in the game. Get your knights and bishops out before your rooks and queen. Always think a move ahead—what will your opponent do next? Don\'t forget to castle to keep your king safe. Try not to create weaknesses, such as doubled or isolated pawns. Be mindful of hanging pieces—don\'t leave pieces unprotected. Connect your rooks by getting your pieces off the back rank. Look for forks and other tactical opportunities to win material. Keep your king active in the endgame—it becomes a powerful piece. If in doubt, try to trade pieces when you are ahead in material. Avoid unnecessary pawn moves; they can\'t move backward. Use the pin and skewer tactics to put pressure on your opponent. Develop with a purpose—every move should improve your position. Control open files with your rooks, especially in the endgame. Make sure your pieces are working together rather than isolated. Practice spotting common tactics like pins, forks, and discovered attacks. Develop your pieces toward the center, where they have more control. When attacking, try to bring more pieces into the action. Be careful with your pawn structure; pawns can be both strengths and weaknesses. Use the rule of squares to calculate if a pawn can promote in the endgame. Avoid moving the pawns in front of your castled king without reason. The bishop pair can be very strong in open positions; keep them if possible. Pay attention to weak squares that you or your opponent can control. Look for forcing moves—checks, captures, and threats are often key. Don\'t exchange pieces without a good reason; only trade if it benefits your position. Keep an eye on your opponent\'s threats and counter them effectively. Aim to put your pieces on active squares where they control the most space. Keep learning—study tactics, openings, and endgames to improve.
